data.title: St. Paul natives’ action thriller owes a lot to Highland Park
data.meta_description: A St. Paul family's trips to Thailand and a St. Paul man's plane crash come together in unexpected ways in "No Escape," the new movie from Highland Park natives John Erick Dowdle and Drew Dowdle.
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

Also see the review: Highland Park natives’ latest film offers no escape from relentless horror

A St. Paul family’s trips to Thailand and a St. Paul man’s plane crash come together in unexpected ways in “No Escape,” the new movie from Highland Park natives John Erick Dowdle and Drew Dowdle.

The plane crash almost killed their dad, John Dowdle. It brought the brothers to his bedside while he recuperated and led to their film collaborations, which have included “Devil” and “Quarantine.” The 2006 Thailand trip nearly got some of the family involved in a government meltdown, which is the subject of “No Escape,” opening in theaters Wednesday.

“Right as we got there, a coup happened. They overthrew the prime minister and generals took over the government,” said John, who traveled to Thailand with his dad (Drew was at a friend’s wedding in Scotland at the time). That trip sent his mind back to his previous trip to Thailand with his family.

“We had been there before with my two little sisters, Lindsay and Claire, who we call the Beeze,” John Dowdle says. “The whole time I was there in 2006, I was thinking what that would have been like if I were a dad who was there with two little kids.”

That is what happens in “No Escape.” Jack and Annie Dwyer (Owen Wilson and Lake Bell) relocate to an unnamed southeast Asian country with their daughters, Lucy and Beeze, and are immediately swept into a violent overthrow of the government, one that specifically targets outsiders from America.

The Dowdles’ script for “No Escape” (they co-write, but John directs the movies and Drew produces) began coming together not long after the 2006 trip. By 2008, they were ready to make a trip to Cambodia and Thailand to look for locations — even though they were on their own dime because, at that point, no movie studio had signed up to pay for the trip.

“That was the first bad decision,” joked Drew, who was in the Twin Cities earlier this week with his brother to do interviews and host a screening of the thriller. (Another Dowdle brother, Ryan, worked as a wardrobe assistant on the film.) “But a lot of the details in the movie come directly from that trip. We shot 10,000 photos …”

“… and we recorded sounds in the jungle. All of that kind of stuff was useful,” added John, who, like his brother, is a graduate of St. Paul’s St. Thomas Academy (John in 1991, Drew in 1993).

As they worked to put together financing, the brothers moved on to other projects, but “No Escape” — originally known as “The Coup” — remained in the back of their minds. And it has turned out to be a lucky thing it did. After more than a decade of working on low-budget productions, “No Escape” — both their biggest-budget movie and the one with the biggest stars (Pierce Brosnan is also in the film, playing a shadowy stranger) — has earned them the Hollywood attention they’ve been hoping for all those years.

Having been slotted in a low-budget horror niche, the Dowdles said now they’re getting meetings for more prestigious material: political thrillers, adventures based on true stories and adaptations of novels. They have four projects in the works, any of which could be ready to go later this year if studio backing comes together. At least one of those projects would be a natural to shoot in northern Minnesota.

“We’d love to shoot a project here. We’ve talked to the (Minnesota) film board a lot,” said John, noting that where they make their movies usually comes down to which state or country can offer the best incentives package to the studio. “We’d really love to work with them to make it an easier place to shoot.”

Whichever of those projects the Dowdles proceed with, it’s likely little snippets of their lives will creep into it. In addition to memories of their younger sisters, “No Escape” is also influenced by John’s son and daughter with his wife, Stacy Chbosky, an actress who plays two small roles in the film — and who, John gleefully noted, gets killed in both of them. The kinds of decisions that parents must make are peppered throughout the film as the Dwyers struggle to survive.

“We like to say the movie is a metaphor for raising kids,” John said of a charged “No Escape” scene in which one parent tries to protect the kids from their new, violent reality while the other insists the children need to know what’s going on. “You want to teach the kids about life but, at the same time, you also don’t want them to be afraid all the time.”

While they’re on the run, the Dwyers try to balance those two impulses, learning what could be called extreme parenting. Not surprisingly, they are most successful at evading their pursuers when they work together.

Even the little girls end up contributing, unexpectedly, to the effort to keep their family alive. That happens in a scene where the family tries to read a map that’s printed in a language they don’t understand — a scene that also was loosely inspired by the Dowdles’ youth in Highland Park.

“Our little sister, Lindsay, would come up with things out of nowhere all the time,” Drew said.

“I remember one time in high school you started a grease fire and you’re running around, not knowing what to do and she’s like, ‘Baking soda!’ ” added John.

That sort of problem-solving ability is evident throughout “No Escape,” which is a thriller but which also says that no matter what adventure you’re on — whether making a movie, recuperating from a plane crash or surviving the violent overthrow of a government — it helps to have family on your side.

Chris Hewitt can be reached at 651-228-5552. Follow him on twitter.com/ChrisHMovie.

Originally Published: August 24, 2015 at 11:01 p.m.
